title: Is there a checklist of top 10 things to do to market a self-published book? - Quora

response.answer_text: That’s a tough one! and I’m not sure there is a top 10 list. The first thing I would suggest is make sure you deliver a well edited book, try to keep the grammatical and spelling errors down to a minimum. After that it’s kind of like seek and find, how do you make the masses aware of your book, without trying to hard sell it? There’s a key right there as far as I’m concerned. You don’t know me from Adam, but I’m going to let you know right now that I have some pretty good books that you need to check out on Amazon/Kindle. Oh, and by the way if you’ll give me your e-mail address, I’ll add it to my growing collection of people I have permission to bother with my solicitations. How do you like that? what is your reaction to that? I don’t think that’s the way to market your book, but that’s just me. So how do you market your book? You’ve got to make people aware of it, but how? Is there a way to get your self a few die hard fans? Word of mouth is key in the promotion of your book! I’ve advertised give a ways on Craig’s List with mine, it’ll get you a few people, but I think they’re mainly just curious. There is no ironed out straight path to it, but there are plenty of outlets available to getting your book out there. As far as mass appeal, it probably won’t happen over night, write another one! while you’re waiting to be discovered. I started back in January with one e-book. I didn’t light up the skies with sales or anything remarkable, I just kept writing in between setting things up for a digital platform. I almost have that in place, and I have 7 books available on Kindle. I’m still pondering ways to create a means of that stuff going viral, and I think that’s why it’s important to have your platform in place. If you get anything out of this it’s figure out how to go Viral! and have your Digital platform in place! Good Luck! Robert

The cover should reflect the genre and expectations of the readers of the genre.The blurb should be enticing without giving the plot away or containing back story.The book should be edited and proofread, then continually proofread by the author until no errors are found. (This wont guarantee there are none, but lessen the likelihood.)Especially the first 10% of the book should hook the reader and make them want to read the rest. Part of this is the writing, and part of it is making sure its polished so well, there are no obvious errors visible.There is no point in marketing if the book itself hasn’t been presented properly.Use the backmatter. Advertise your other books there. Solicit joining your mailing list, Amazon, Bookbub and Goodreads follows, your Facebook group and page, Instagram account, etc.Join an author discussion forum and learn where others market for your genre. Learn what they recommend doing, and not doing.The best way of advertising a book, is to write another one in the same series, or a spin off series. You will notice there is no marketing advice in the above. Marketing is what you do last. If get the above wrong, no amount of marketing will work for you. For example, if you get the cover wrong, and the blurb puts people off, or the sample reads badly or contains a lot of obvious errors, your marketing money will be wasted.
